headline.main: In the struggle for time and space, public service spots are finding new ways to hold their own.

docs.lead_paragraph: PICTURE the last public service announcement that you saw on television. You were up late that night, weren't you? About a third of the public service spots distributed last year by the Advertising Council, the biggest producer of public service campaigns, appeared on TV from 1 a.m. to 6 a.m. Despite the council's best efforts, the story remains the same today.
docs.snippet: The Advertising Council, the biggest producer of public service campaigns, says that its tactics to secure more and better donated time and space are paying off.

headline.main: Council Bills Seek Medical Gear for the Obese

docs.lead_paragraph: Troubled by accounts of seriously overweight patients unable to find adequate medical care, the City Council is taking up legislation that would require some public hospitals and ambulances to have stretchers, beds and wheelchairs large enough to accommodate the obese. One of two obesity-related bills introduced at a Council meeting yesterday would mandate that one city-run hospital in each borough have specialized equipment on hand to be used for people who weigh more than 400 pounds. The other bill would ensure that each borough have at least two ambulances capable of transporting someone who weighs 500 pounds or more.
docs.snippet: Troubled by accounts of seriously overweight patients unable to find adequate medical care, the City Council is taking up legislation that would require some public hospitals and ambulances to have stretchers, beds and wheelchairs large enough to...

headline.main: Low Cholesterol? Don't Brag Quite Yet

docs.lead_paragraph: Not all that long ago, a low cholesterol score was seen as a sign of relative good health and a low risk of heart disease. But increasingly, doctors are identifying a group of people whose levels of L.D.L, the so-called bad cholesterol, are low, but who still appear to be at increased risk for atherosclerosis, heart attack and stroke.
docs.snippet: Why some people with low cholesterol may still be at risk for heart disease.
